Yes, there were definitely conflicts between those who wanted a loose confederation and those who wanted a unified nation-state. Prince Klemens von Metternich, the architect of the Confederation, believed that a loose confederation was the best way to maintain peace and stability in Europe, as it allowed for cooperation and shared governance without threatening the power and sovereignty of individual states. On the other hand, Johann Wolfgang von Goethe and other intellectuals and nationalists felt that a united German nation-state was necessary to achieve true independence and self-determination.

These conflicting views on the form and purpose of the German Confederation led to debates and tensions between different factions, and these tensions remained unresolved for decades. Ultimately, it was the rise of Prussian nationalism and the efforts of Chancellor Otto von Bismarck that led to the creation of a unified German state in 1871.
